steps.title: Look for thin, irregular white, yellow, or brown patches.
steps.content: Look for thin, irregular white, yellow, or brown patches. The patches could be irregular-shaped splotches or rings. You will likely see the soil through the grass, which will look frayed. The patches will likely continue to grow in diameter over time. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for gray, black, orange, red, or purple spots on grass or stems.
steps.content: Watch for gray, black, orange, red, or purple spots on grass or stems. This can be a sign of leaf spot, a fungal infection that will travel down the blades of grass, resulting in root rot. Over time, your grass will die. The fungal infection will continue to spread outward if it's left untreated. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Check for gray, black, or pink powder or threadlike coating on the grass.
steps.content: Check for gray, black, or pink powder or threadlike coating on the grass. This can indicate red thread, pink patch, or powdery mildew. Red-thread and pink patch often occur together, and they spread easily. Powdery mildew can also spread, though it's not likely to penetrate the soil.

steps.title: Notice grass that has become dark, wet, and slimy.
steps.content: Notice grass that has become dark, wet, and slimy. This is called grease spot, which is most common in humid environments. If you have grease spot, you may also notice a white, cotton-like fungus growing around the slimy area. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid tracking the fungus across other parts of your yard.
steps.content: Avoid tracking the fungus across other parts of your yard. Fungal diseases spread easily, so your footsteps, lawnmower, or wheelbarrow can easily allow the disease to spread to healthy parts of your yard. When you must walk through the area, cover your footwear with plastic wrap, removing it before stepping onto clean grass. [4] X Research source Be sure to catch and remove all grass clippings when mowing.

steps.title: Apply a fungicide to your lawn.
steps.content: Apply a fungicide to your lawn. Choose a fungicide that addresses the infection you have in your yard. There are two types of fungicide: contact and systemic. Contact fungicide comes in a liquid. It coats the surface of the plant and kills the spores it comes in contact with. It normally wears off fast and is minimally effective. Systemic fungicide is usually granular and dissolves into the soil, where it's taken up into the root system. This treatment lasts longer.You should follow the instructions on your product's packaging. Benomyl is potent against a range of fungi, including snow mold, brown patch, and dollar spot. Triadimefon works well against anthracnose and rust. Chlorothalonil does best against brown patch and red thread. Fairy ring has no cure once it establishes itself in your lawn, and fungicides are only effective against necrotic ring spot if accompanied by a de-thatching process.

steps.title: Try natural treatments that kill fungicide.
steps.content: Try natural treatments that kill fungicide. If you don't like using chemicals, there are a few natural options you can try. Neem oil, compost tea, and baking soda solutions can all kill fungus. [5] X Research source Pour or sprinkle the natural treatment over the infected patch. These natural options work best on new growth or small quantities of fungus. Keep other people and pets away from the affected site for a few days after you apply the natural treatment.

steps.title: Expect some fungal infections to be seasonal.
steps.content: Expect some fungal infections to be seasonal. Certain fungal infections are affected by the weather. Gray snow mold usually goes away when the weather warms to temperatures above 40 degrees Fahrenheit (4 degrees Celsius). Rapidly warming weather could kill the mold immediately. Similarly, some thread molds go away when the sun warms and dries the lawn. [6] X Research source Other fungi, like powdery mold, thrive in dry weather with high humidity. [7] X Research source Fungal infections can go away on their own if you properly maintain your yard.

steps.title: Water your lawn only when necessary.
steps.content: Water your lawn only when necessary. Most yards need only 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) of water weekly, but homeowners may water their lawn more than is necessary. Many fungi thrive in moist conditions, so overwatering makes it easier for fungi to grow. On the other hand, don't allow your lawn to get too dry, either. Dry soil will lead to weak grass that is more susceptible to disease. It's best to water in the morning because your soil will absorb the water it needs, allowing the extra water to evaporate throughout the rest of the day. [8] X Research source If you use a sprinkler, test it to make sure it is working properly. Measure how much water it is distributing in your yard so that you can adjust accordingly.

steps.title: Use a low-nitrogen, slow-release fertilizer.
steps.content: Use a low-nitrogen, slow-release fertilizer. Fungal infections can occur due to either under- or over-fertilization. To maintain balance, choose an organic, slow-release fertilizer with potassium and nitrogen. Fertilizer can help your lawn fight off an infection by strengthening the grass. [9] X Research source Avoid too much nitrogen because it can cause fast growing grass that is weak, making it more susceptible to infection. Always follow the instructions on the packaging to avoid misapplication.

steps.title: Remove all leaves from your yard in winter.
steps.content: Remove all leaves from your yard in winter. Gray snow mold can grow under fallen leaves if you leave them on your lawn. To prevent mold growth, rake up and remove all leaves before it snows.

steps.title: Keep your lawnmower at the highest setting.
steps.content: Keep your lawnmower at the highest setting. You should only cut â…“ of the grass height at any given time. Rather than cutting your grass short, you should leave your lawn lush and thick because the fresh growth is weaker, making it more susceptible to the fungus. While it may be more work, long grass will keep your lawn healthier. [10] X Research source Keep your lawnmower blades sharp and clean. Mow your lawn a little shorter than usual before snow comes to help protect against snow mold.

steps.title: De-thatch your lawn to remove layers of dead plants.
steps.content: De-thatch your lawn to remove layers of dead plants. Thatch is usually made up of dead grass, leaves, roots, and stems, which can smother the soil. Your soil needs air circulation to prevent fungal infections, so de-thatching can help prevent an infection. [11] X Research source It's best to use a mechanical, gas powered de-thatch machine that could be rented at the local home improvement center or equipment rental store. De-thatching is usually done in the spring.

steps.title: Aerate your yard annually to break up the soil.
steps.content: Aerate your yard annually to break up the soil. Aeration will loosen the soil, preventing it from becoming too compacted. This is very important and should be done at least once a year ensure that water, fertilizers, and lawn treatments can penetrate into the soil. Otherwise, the roots of the grass will not be able to fully absorb nutrients or treatments. [12] X Research source You can rent an aeration machine to help you loosen the soil.

steps.title: Top-dress your yard annually after the aeration.
steps.content: Top-dress your yard annually after the aeration. Top-dressing your yard means adding a layer of rich, well-draining material that will help you improve the quality of your soil. It will likely include materials like sharp sand, loam, peat, or compost. The top-dressing can improve the health of your grass and help it drain better, preventing excessive moisture. Spread your top-dressing over the yard, raking it across the soil to create an even layer. [13] X Research source Before you top-dress, you should de-thatch and aerate your soil.
